_**Downton Abbey**_ is a [historical period
drama](/wiki/Historical_period_drama "Historical period drama") television
series created by [Julian Fellowes](/wiki/Julian_Fellowes "Julian Fellowes")
and co-produced by [Carnival Films](/wiki/Carnival_Films "Carnival Films") and
[Masterpiece](/wiki/Masterpiece_\(TV_series\) "Masterpiece \(TV series\)").[1]
It first aired on [ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV network\)") in the
[United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") on 26 September 2010,
and on [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS") in the [United States](/wiki/United_States
"United States") on 9 January 2011 as part of the _Masterpiece Classic_
anthology.

The series, set in the fictional [Yorkshire](/wiki/Yorkshire "Yorkshire")
[country estate](/wiki/English_country_house "English country house") of
Downton Abbey between 1912 and 1926, depicts the lives of the
[aristocratic](/wiki/Aristocracy_\(class\) "Aristocracy \(class\)") Crawley
family and their [domestic servants](/wiki/Domestic_worker "Domestic worker")
in the post-[Edwardian era](/wiki/Edwardian_era "Edwardian era")—with the
great events in history having an effect on their lives and on the British
social hierarchy. Events depicted throughout the series include news of the
[sinking of the RMS _Titanic_](/wiki/Sinking_of_the_Titanic "Sinking of the
Titanic") in the first series; the outbreak of the [First World
War](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), the [Spanish influenza
pandemic](/wiki/1918_flu_pandemic "1918 flu pandemic"), and the [Marconi
scandal](/wiki/Marconi_scandal "Marconi scandal") in the second series; the
[Irish War of Independence](/wiki/Irish_War_of_Independence "Irish War of
Independence") leading to the formation of the [Irish Free
State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State") in the third series; the
[Teapot Dome scandal](/wiki/Teapot_Dome_scandal "Teapot Dome scandal") in the
fourth series; and the [British general election of
1923](/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_1923 "United Kingdom general
election, 1923"), the [Jallianwala Bagh
massacre](/wiki/Jallianwala_Bagh_massacre "Jallianwala Bagh massacre"), and
the [Beer Hall Putsch](/wiki/Beer_Hall_Putsch "Beer Hall Putsch") in the fifth
series. The sixth and final series introduces the rise of the working class
during the [interwar period](/wiki/Interwar_period "Interwar period") and
hints towards the eventual decline of the British aristocracy.

_Downton Abbey_ has received acclaim from television critics and won numerous
accolades, including a [Golden Globe Award for Best Miniseries or Television
Film](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Miniseries_or_Television_Film "Golden
Globe Award for Best Miniseries or Television Film") and a [Primetime Emmy
Award for Outstanding Miniseries or
Movie](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Miniseries_or_Movie
"Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Miniseries or Movie"). It was recognised
by _[Guinness World Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World
Records")_ as the most critically acclaimed English-language television series
of 2011. It earned the most nominations of any international television series
in the history of the [Primetime Emmy Awards](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Awards
"Primetime Emmy Awards"), with twenty-seven in total (after two series).[2] It
was the most watched television series on both ITV and PBS, and subsequently
became the most successful British costume drama series since the 1981
television serial of _[Brideshead
Revisited](/wiki/Brideshead_Revisited_\(TV_serial\) "Brideshead Revisited \(TV
serial\)")_.[3] By the third series, it had become one of the most widely
watched television drama shows in the world.[4]

On 26 March 2015, Carnival Films and ITV announced that the sixth series would
be the last. It aired on ITV between 20 September 2015 and 8 November 2015.
The final episode, serving as the annual Christmas special, was broadcast on
25 December 2015. Although there are no plans in place, there are strong
rumours of a future film adaptation, with executive producer [Gareth
Neame](/wiki/Gareth_Neame "Gareth Neame") saying that he was "very interested"
and bookmakers Ladbrokes stating that "it only looks like being a matter of
time before the film is released".[5]

## Plot overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot overview")]

Main article: [List of Downton Abbey
episodes](/wiki/List_of_Downton_Abbey_episodes "List of Downton Abbey
episodes")

### Series 1:
2010[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Series 1: 2010")]

Main article: [Downton Abbey (series 1)](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_1\)
"Downton Abbey \(series 1\)")

The first series, comprising seven episodes, explores the lives of the
fictional Crawley family, the hereditary Earls of Grantham, and their domestic
servants beginning the day after the [historic](/wiki/Historic "Historic")
[sinking of the RMS _Titanic_](/wiki/Sinking_of_the_RMS_Titanic "Sinking of
the RMS Titanic") on 14/15 April 1912. The storyline centres on the [fee
tail](/wiki/Fee_tail "Fee tail") or "entail" governing the titled elite, which
endows title and estate exclusively to [heirs male](/wiki/Primogeniture
"Primogeniture"). As part of the backstory, the main character, Robert, Earl
of Grantham, had resolved past financial difficulties by marrying Cora
Levinson, an American heiress. Her considerable dowry is contractually
incorporated into the comital entail in perpetuity. Robert and Cora have three
daughters and no sons.

As the eldest daughter, Lady Mary Crawley was to marry her second cousin, son
of the then-[heir presumptive](/wiki/Heir_presumptive "Heir presumptive"). The
first episode begins as news reaches Downton Abbey that both Grantham heirs
perished in the sinking of the _Titanic_. A distant male cousin,
[solicitor](/wiki/Solicitor "Solicitor") Matthew Crawley, is from an [upper-
middle-class](/wiki/Social_structure_of_the_United_Kingdom "Social structure
of the United Kingdom") family – as his mother reminds him in episode one of
series one. Matthew Crawley becomes the new heir. The plot centres on the
relationship between Lady Mary and Matthew, who resists embracing an
aristocratic lifestyle.

A subplot involves John Bates, Lord Grantham's new valet, and Thomas Barrow,
who resents Bates replacing him and causing Barrow to be demoted back to
footman. Bates and Thomas remain at odds as Barrow works to sabotage Bates
after learning he was recently released from jail for theft. In the story
line, Barrow, a gay man in late Edwardian England, aided by Miss O'Brien, Lady
Grantham's maid, creates havoc for most of the staff. Barrow is caught
stealing but hands in his notice as he has joined the Royal Army Medical
Corps. Matthew eventually falls in love with Lady Mary, but she rejects his
proposal. Cora becomes pregnant, but miscarries after O'Brien, mistakenly
believing she was to be fired, retaliates by leaving a bar of soap on the
slippery bathroom floor. The series ends just after the [Archduke Franz
Ferdinand's](/wiki/Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria "Archduke Franz
Ferdinand of Austria") assassination and the outbreak of the [First World
War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War") in July 1914.

### Series 2:
2011[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Series 2: 2011")]

Main article: [Downton Abbey (series 2)](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_2\)
"Downton Abbey \(series 2\)")

The second series comprises eight episodes and runs from the [Battle of the
Somme](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme "Battle of the Somme") in 1916 to the [1918
Spanish flu pandemic](/wiki/1918_Spanish_flu_pandemic "1918 Spanish flu
pandemic"). During the war, Downton Abbey is temporarily converted into an
officers' convalescent hospital.

Matthew becomes engaged to Lavinia Swire, a wealthy solicitor's daughter, and
joins the British Army as an officer. William Mason, the 2nd footman, finally
gets permission from his father to join the Army and becomes Matthew's soldier
servant. Unfortunately, both are injured in a bomb blast. William dies from
his wounds after a deathbed marriage to Daisy, the kitchen maid. Daisy never
loved William but Mrs Patmore, Downton's cook, pressured her to make William's
last days happy by marrying him.

Mary finally acknowledges her feelings for Matthew, but becomes engaged to Sir
Richard Carlisle, a powerful and ruthless newspaper mogul. Their relationship
is rocky, but Mary is bound to Carlisle after he squashes a story regarding
her past scandalous indiscretion. Bates's wife, Vera, repeatedly causes
trouble for John and Anna, who is now his fiancée, and threatens to expose a
Crawley secret. When Mrs Bates mysteriously dies, Bates is arrested on
suspicion of her murder. Matthew and Mary realise they are in love but Matthew
honourably remains committed to marrying Lavinia. Unknown to him, a devastated
Lavinia overhears Matthew and Mary declare their love. The Spanish influenza
epidemic hits Downton Abbey at the end of the war. Cora, taken seriously ill,
survives, but Lavinia, also infected, dies. Barrow is rehired at Downton after
helping the staff during the outbreak. Mary and Matthew reunite, while Bates
is found guilty of murder and sentenced to death.

Lady Sybil, the youngest Crawley daughter, who hated her stifling aristocratic
life, falls in love with Tom Branson, the chauffeur with strong socialist
beliefs. They elope to Ireland after receiving Lord Grantham's reluctant
blessing.

Ethel Parks, a new housemaid, has a relationship with one of the injured
officers, Major Bryant. Mrs Hughes finds them together in bed and dismisses
Ethel, but takes pity on her and helps her when Ethel realises that she is
pregnant. She has a baby boy and names him Charlie after his father, but Major
Bryant refuses to believe that he is the baby's father.

### Series 3:
2012[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Series 3: 2012")]

Main article: [Downton Abbey (series 3)](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_3\)
"Downton Abbey \(series 3\)")

In the third series, 1920–1921, Mary has ended her engagement to Richard
Carlisle, despite his vindictive threats to expose her past indiscretion. Mary
and Matthew are married in the series première, but Robert (Lord Grantham)
learns that the bulk of the family's fortune (including Cora's dowry) has been
lost, due to his well-intentioned, but bad investment. In the meantime, Edith
has fallen hard for Sir Anthony Strallen, whom Robert discourages from
marrying Edith due to his age and infirm condition. At Edith's insistence,
Robert gives in and welcomes Sir Anthony, but the latter cannot accept the
fact that there is no reservation from the Grantham family, and at the altar
on their wedding day announces that he cannot go through with the marriage,
devastating Edith.

Meanwhile, due to dislike and increasing tension, Bates' cellmate tries to
sabotage him with a crime that will ruin his chances for a pardon, but Bates
is informed by a fellow prisoner about the search, which results in the guards
not finding what they are seeking. Back at Downton, Mrs Hughes finds out she
may have breast cancer, which only some of the household hear about, causing
deep concern, but the tumour turns out to be benign, much to everyone's
relief. Tom Branson and Lady Sybil, now pregnant, return to Downton after Tom
is implicated in the burning of an Irish aristocrat's house. After Matthew's
reluctance to accept an inheritance from Lavinia's recently deceased father
and then Robert's reluctance in turn to accept that inheritance as a gift,
Matthew and Robert reach a compromise in which Matthew accepts and uses the
inheritance to invest in Downton, giving him an equal say in how the estate is
run.

Tragedy strikes when Sybil dies from [pre-eclampsia](/wiki/Pre-eclampsia "Pre-
eclampsia"), shortly after giving birth. Tom, devastated, names his daughter
Sybil, after his late wife. Bates is released from prison after Anna uncovers
evidence clearing him of his wife's murder. Tom becomes the new estate agent
at the suggestion of Dowager Countess Violet. Barrow and Miss O'Brien have a
falling out, after which O'Brien leads Barrow to believe that Jimmy, the new
footman, is sexually attracted to him. Barrow enters Jimmy's room and kisses
him while he is sleeping, which wakes him up shocked and confused. In the end,
Lord Grantham defuses the situation. The family visits Lady Violet's niece
Susan and her husband "Shrimpie", the Marquess of Flintshire, in Scotland,
while awaiting the birth of Matthew and Lady Mary's baby. The Marquess
confides to Robert that the estate is bankrupt and will be sold, making Robert
recognise that Downton has been saved through Matthew and Tom's efforts to
modernise. Mary gives birth to the new heir, but Matthew dies in a car crash
while driving home from the hospital.

### Series 4:
2013[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Series 4: 2013")]

Main article: [Downton Abbey (series 4)](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_4\)
"Downton Abbey \(series 4\)")

In series four, 1922–1923, Cora's maid Miss O'Brien, desiring adventure and
travel, leaves to serve Lady Flintshire in India. Cora hires Edna Braithwaite,
who had previously been fired for her interest in Tom. Eventually the
situation blows up, and Edna is replaced by Miss Baxter.

Lady Mary deeply mourns Matthew's death. Matthew's newly-found will states
Mary is to be his sole heir and thus gives her management over his share of
the estate until their son, George, comes of age. With Tom's encouragement,
Mary assumes a more active role in running Downton. Two new suitors — Lord
Gillingham and Charles Blake — arrive at Downton, though Mary, still grieving,
is not interested. Middle daughter Lady Edith, who has begun writing a weekly
newspaper column, and Michael Gregson, her editor, fall in love. Due to
British law, he is unable to divorce his wife, who is mentally ill and in an
asylum. Gregson travels to Germany to seek citizenship there, enabling him to
divorce, but is killed by Hitler's [Brownshirts](/wiki/Brownshirts
"Brownshirts") during riots. Edith is left pregnant and with help from her
paternal aunt, Lady Rosamund, secretly gives birth to a daughter. She intends
to give her up for adoption in Switzerland and places the baby with adoptive
parents, but reclaims her after arranging a new adoptive family on the estate.
Mr and Mrs Drewe of Yew Tree Farm take the baby in and raise her as their own.

Anna is raped by Lord Gillingham's valet, Mr Green, which Mr Bates later
discovers. Subsequently, Mr Green is killed in a London street accident. A
local schoolteacher, Sarah Bunting and Tom begin a friendship, though Robert
(Lord Grantham) despises her due to her openly vocal anti-aristocracy views.
In the final Christmas special, Sampson, a card sharp, steals a letter from
the Prince of Wales to his mistress, Rose's friend [Freda
Ward](/wiki/Freda_Dudley_Ward "Freda Dudley Ward"), which, if made public,
would create a scandal; the entire Crawley family connives to retrieve it,
though it is Bates who extracts the letter from Sampson's overcoat, and it is
returned to Mrs Ward.

### Series 5:
2014[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Series 5: 2014")]

Main article: [Downton Abbey (series 5)](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_5\)
"Downton Abbey \(series 5\)")

In series five, 1924, a Russian exile, Prince Kuragin, wishes to renew his
past affections for the Dowager Countess. Violet instead locates his wife in
Hong Kong and reunites the Prince and his estranged wife. Scotland Yard and
the local police investigate Green's death. Violet learns about Edith's
daughter, young Marigold. Meanwhile, Mrs Drewe, not knowing Marigold's true
parentage, resents Edith's constant visits. To increase his chances with Mary,
Charles Blake plots to reunite Gillingham and his ex-fiancée, Mabel. After
Edith inherits Michael Gregson's publishing company, she removes Marigold from
the Drewes and relocates to London. Bricker, an art expert interested in one
of Downton's paintings, shows his real intentions toward Cora and is thrown
out by Robert, causing a temporary rift between them.

Mrs Patmore's decision to invest her inheritance in real estate inspires
Carson, Downton's butler, to do likewise. He suggests that head housekeeper
Mrs Hughes invest with him; she confesses she has no money due to supporting a
mentally incapacitated sister. The Crawleys' cousin, Lady Rose, daughter of
Lord and Lady Flintshire, becomes engaged to Atticus Aldridge, son of Lord and
Lady Sinderby. Lord Sinderby strongly objects to Atticus' marrying outside the
Jewish faith. Lord Merton proposes to Isobel Crawley (Matthew's mother). She
accepts, but later ends the engagement due to Lord Merton's sons' disparaging
comments over her commoner background. Lady Flintshire employs underhanded
schemes to derail Rose and Atticus's engagement, including announcing to
everyone at the wedding that she and her husband are divorcing, intending to
cause a scandal to stop Rose's marriage to Atticus; they are married anyway.

When Anna is arrested on suspicion of Green's murder, Bates writes a false
confession before fleeing to Ireland. Miss Baxter and Molesley, a footman, are
able to prove that Bates was in York at the time of the murder. This new
information allows Anna to be released. Cora eventually learns the truth about
Marigold, and wants her raised at Downton; Marigold is presented as Edith's
ward, but Robert and Tom eventually discern the truth: only Mary is unaware.
When a war memorial is unveiled in the town, Robert arranges for a separate
plaque to honour Mrs Patmore's late nephew, who was shot for cowardice and
excluded from his own village's memorial.

Lord and Lady Sinderby invite the Crawleys to their country estate for a
shooting party. While there, Lady Rose, with help from the Crawleys, defuses a
near–personal disaster for Lord Sinderby, earning his gratitude and securing
his approval of Rose. A second footman, Andy, is hired on Barrow's
recommendation. During the annual Downton Abbey Christmas celebration, Tom
Branson announces he is moving to America to work for his cousin, taking
daughter Sybil with him. Mr Carson proposes marriage to Mrs Hughes and she
accepts.

### Series 6:
2015[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Series 6: 2015")]

Main article: [Downton Abbey (series 6)](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_6\)
"Downton Abbey \(series 6\)")

In series six, 1925, changes are once again afoot at Downton Abbey as the
middle class rises and more bankrupted aristocrats are forced to sell off
their large estates. Downton must do more to ensure its future survival;
reductions in staff are considered, forcing Barrow to look for a job
elsewhere. Lady Mary defies a blackmailer, who is thwarted by Lord Grantham.
Lady Mary becomes the estate agent. Edith is more hands-on in running her
magazine and hires a female editor. Lady Violet and Isobel once again draw
battle lines as a government take-over of the local hospital is considered.

Meanwhile, Anna suffers repeated miscarriages. Lady Mary takes her to a
specialist, who diagnoses a treatable condition, and she becomes pregnant
again. Mr Carson and Mrs Hughes hold their wedding reception at the
schoolhouse, during which Tom Branson reappears with Sybil, having returned to
Downton for good. Coyle, who tricked Baxter into stealing, is convicted after
she and other witnesses are persuaded to testify. After Mrs Drewe kidnaps
Marigold when Edith is not looking, the Drewes vacate Yew Tree Farm; Daisy
convinces Tom Branson to ask Lord Grantham to give her father-in-law, Mr
Mason, the tenancy. Andy, a footman, offers to help Mr Mason so he can learn
about farming, but is held back by his illiteracy; Mr Barrow offers to teach
Andy to read.

Robert suffers a near-fatal health crisis. Previous episodes alluded to health
problems for Robert; his ulcer bursts and he is rushed to the hospital for
emergency surgery. The operation is successful, but Mary and Tom must take
over Downton's operations. Larry Merton's fiancée, Amelia, encourages Lord
Merton and Isobel Crawley to renew their engagement, but Lady Violet rightly
suspects Amelia wants Isobel to be Lord Merton's caretaker in his old age.[6]
Daisy and Mr Molesley score high marks on their academic exams; Molesley's are
so exceptional that he is offered a teaching position at the school. Mary
breaks off with Henry Talbot, unable to live with the constant fear he could
be killed in a car race. Bertie Pelham proposes to Edith, but she hesitates to
accept because of Marigold. Lady Violet, upset over Lady Grantham replacing
her as hospital president, abruptly departs for a long cruise to restore her
equanimity.

Bertie Pelham unexpectedly succeeds his late second cousin as marquess, and
Edith accepts him. Then Mary spitefully exposes Marigold's parentage, causing
Bertie to walk out. Tom confronts Mary over her spitefulness and her true
feelings for Henry. Despondent Barrow attempts suicide, and is saved by
Baxter, causing Robert and Mr Carson to reconsider Barrow's position at
Downton. Mary and Henry reunite and are married. Mary apologises to Edith, and
the sisters reconcile. Mrs Patmore's new bed and breakfast business is tainted
by scandal, but saved when the Crawleys appear there publicly. Mary arranges a
surprise meeting for Edith and Bertie, Bertie proposes again, and Edith
accepts. Edith tells Bertie's moralistic mother about Marigold; she turns
against the match, but is won over after all by Edith's honesty. Barrow finds
a position as butler and leaves Downton on good terms, but he is unhappy at
his new post.

Lord Merton is diagnosed with terminal [pernicious
anemia](/wiki/Pernicious_anemia "Pernicious anemia"), and Amelia blocks Isobel
from seeing him. Goaded by Lady Violet, Isobel pushes into the Merton house,
and announces she will take Lord Merton away and marry him – to his delight.
Lord Merton is later correctly diagnosed with non-fatal anemia. Robert resents
Cora's frequent absences as the hospital president, but eventually comes to
admire her ability. Henry and Tom go into business together selling cars,
while Mary announces her pregnancy. Molesley accepts a permanent teaching
position and he and Miss Baxter promise to continue seeing each other. Daisy
and Andy finally acknowledge their feelings; Daisy decides to move to the farm
with her father-in-law. Carson develops palsy and must retire. Lord Grantham
suggests Barrow return as butler, with Carson in an oversight role. Edith and
Bertie are married on New Year's Eve. Lady Rose and Atticus return for the
wedding. Anna goes into labour during the reception, and she and Bates become
parents to a healthy son.

## Crawley
family[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Crawley family")]

The series is set in fictional Downton Abbey, a [Yorkshire](/wiki/Yorkshire
"Yorkshire") [country house](/wiki/English_country_house "English country
house"), which is the home and seat of the [Earl](/wiki/Earl "Earl") and
[Countess](/wiki/Countess_\(feminine_form_of_earl\) "Countess \(feminine form
of earl\)") of [Grantham](/wiki/Grantham "Grantham"), along with their
children and distant family members. Each series follows the lives of the
[aristocratic](/wiki/Aristocracy_\(class\) "Aristocracy \(class\)") Crawley
family, their friends, and their servants during the reign of King [George
V](/wiki/George_V "George V").

## Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Cast")]

Main article: [List of Downton Abbey
characters](/wiki/List_of_Downton_Abbey_characters "List of Downton Abbey
characters")

The main cast of the Crawley family is led by [Hugh
Bonneville](/wiki/Hugh_Bonneville "Hugh Bonneville") as Robert Crawley, the
Earl of Grantham, and [Elizabeth McGovern](/wiki/Elizabeth_McGovern "Elizabeth
McGovern") as his wife Cora Crawley, the Countess of Grantham. Their three
daughters are depicted by [Michelle Dockery](/wiki/Michelle_Dockery "Michelle
Dockery") as Lady Mary Crawley, [Laura Carmichael](/wiki/Laura_Carmichael
"Laura Carmichael") as Lady Edith Crawley and [Jessica Brown
Findlay](/wiki/Jessica_Brown_Findlay "Jessica Brown Findlay") as Lady Sybil
Crawley (Branson). [Maggie Smith](/wiki/Maggie_Smith "Maggie Smith") is Robert
Crawley's mother Violet, Dowager Countess of Grantham. [Samantha
Bond](/wiki/Samantha_Bond "Samantha Bond") portrays Lady Rosamund Painswick,
Robert's sister who resides in Belgrave Square, London. [Dan
Stevens](/wiki/Dan_Stevens "Dan Stevens") portrays Matthew Crawley, the new
heir, along with [Penelope Wilton](/wiki/Penelope_Wilton "Penelope Wilton") as
his mother, Isobel Crawley, who are brought to Downton. [Allen
Leech](/wiki/Allen_Leech "Allen Leech") begins the series as Tom Branson the
chauffeur but falls in love with Lady Sybil, marries her and becomes the agent
for the estate. Joining the cast in series three is [Lily
James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James") as the Lady Rose MacClare (Aldridge), a
second cousin through Violet's family, who is sent to live with the Crawleys
because her parents are serving the empire in India and, later, remains there
because of family problems. [David Robb](/wiki/David_Robb "David Robb")
portrays Dr. Richard Clarkson, the local town doctor. Other suitors for Lady
Mary's affections during the series include [Tom Cullen](/wiki/Tom_Cullen "Tom
Cullen") as Lord Gillingham, [Julian Ovenden](/wiki/Julian_Ovenden "Julian
Ovenden") as Charles Blake, and [Matthew Goode](/wiki/Matthew_Goode "Matthew
Goode") as Henry Talbot.

Downton Abbey's senior staff are portrayed by [Jim
Carter](/wiki/Jim_Carter_\(actor\) "Jim Carter \(actor\)") as Mr Carson, the
butler, and [Phyllis Logan](/wiki/Phyllis_Logan "Phyllis Logan") as Mrs
Hughes, the housekeeper. Tensions rise when [Rob James-
Collier](/wiki/Rob_James-Collier "Rob James-Collier"), portraying Mr Barrow, a
valet and footman, along with [Siobhan Finneran](/wiki/Siobhan_Finneran
"Siobhan Finneran") as Miss O'Brien, the personal maid to the Countess of
Grantham (up to series three), plot against [Brendan
Coyle](/wiki/Brendan_Coyle "Brendan Coyle") as Mr Bates, the valet to the Earl
of Grantham, and his love interest and eventual wife, Anna ([Joanne
Froggatt](/wiki/Joanne_Froggatt "Joanne Froggatt")), the personal maid to Lady
Mary. [Kevin Doyle](/wiki/Kevin_Doyle_\(actor\) "Kevin Doyle \(actor\)") plays
the unlucky Mr Molesley, valet to Matthew Crawley; he and [Thomas
Howes](/wiki/Thomas_Howes_\(actor\) "Thomas Howes \(actor\)"), as William
Mason the second footman, round off the main, original downstairs staff.

[Matt Milne](/wiki/Matt_Milne "Matt Milne") joins the cast as O'Brien's nephew
Alfred Nugent, the awkward new footman for series three and four, and [Raquel
Cassidy](/wiki/Raquel_Cassidy "Raquel Cassidy") plays Baxter, Cora's personal
maid, who was hired to replace O'Brien. The lower staff includes [Lesley
Nicol](/wiki/Lesley_Nicol_\(actress\) "Lesley Nicol \(actress\)") as Mrs
Patmore the cook, [Sophie McShera](/wiki/Sophie_McShera "Sophie McShera") as
Daisy, the scullery maid who works her way up to assistant cook and marries
William Mason, and [Rose Leslie](/wiki/Rose_Leslie "Rose Leslie") as Gwen
Dawson, a kitchen maid studying to be a secretary in series one. [Amy
Nuttall](/wiki/Amy_Nuttall "Amy Nuttall") plays Ethel Parks, a maid, beginning
in series two and three. [Cara Theobold](/wiki/Cara_Theobold "Cara Theobold")
portrays Ivy Stuart, a kitchen maid, joining the cast for series three and
four. [Ed Speleers](/wiki/Ed_Speleers "Ed Speleers") plays the dashing James
Kent, the second footman from series three through five. In series five and
six [Michael C. Fox](/wiki/Michael_C._Fox "Michael C. Fox") plays Andy Parker,
a replacement footman for James. In series four, five, and six [Andrew
Scarborough](/wiki/Andrew_Scarborough "Andrew Scarborough") plays Tim Drewe, a
farmer of the estate, who helps Lady Edith conceal a big secret.

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Production")]

[Gareth Neame](/wiki/Gareth_Neame "Gareth Neame") of [Carnival
Films](/wiki/Carnival_Films "Carnival Films") conceived the idea of an
[Edwardian-era](/wiki/Edwardian_era "Edwardian era") TV drama set in a country
house and approached Fellowes, who had won an [Academy Award for Best Writing
(Original
Screenplay)](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Writing_\(Original_Screenplay\)
"Academy Award for Best Writing \(Original Screenplay\)") for _[Gosford
Park](/wiki/Gosford_Park "Gosford Park")_. Although Fellowes was reluctant to
work on another project resembling _Gosford_ , within a few weeks he returned
to Neame with an outline of the first series. Influenced by Edith Wharton's
_[The Custom of the Country](/wiki/The_Custom_of_the_Country "The Custom of
the Country")_ ,[7] Fellowes writes the scripts and his wife Emma is an
informal [story editor](/wiki/Story_editor "Story editor").[8]

### Locations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Locations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Highclere_Castle_%28April_2011%29.jpg/220px-
Highclere_Castle_%28April_2011%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Highclere_Castle_\(April_2011\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Highclere_Castle_\(April_2011\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Highclere Castle](/wiki/Highclere_Castle "Highclere Castle"), used for
interior and exterior filming of Downton Abbey

[Highclere Castle](/wiki/Highclere_Castle "Highclere Castle") in north
[Hampshire](/wiki/Hampshire "Hampshire") is used for exterior shots of Downton
Abbey and most of the interior filming.[9][10][11][12] The kitchen, [servants'
quarters](/wiki/Servants%27_quarters "Servants' quarters") and working areas,
and some of the "upstairs" bedrooms were constructed and filmed at [Ealing
Studios](/wiki/Ealing_Studios "Ealing Studios").[13] [Bridgewater
House](/wiki/Bridgewater_House,_Westminster "Bridgewater House, Westminster")
in the St James area of London served as the family's London home.

Film locations in Bampton, Oxfordshire

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Bampton_StMaryV_SE.jpg/131px-
Bampton_StMaryV_SE.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bampton_StMaryV_SE.jpg)

St Mary the Virgin, used as St Michael and All Angels in Downton

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/The_Library-
Bampton.JPG/210px-The_Library-Bampton.JPG)](/wiki/File:The_Library-
Bampton.JPG)

Bampton Library, used as the Downton Cottage Hospital

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/The_Rectory-
Bampton.JPG/210px-The_Rectory-Bampton.JPG)](/wiki/File:The_Rectory-
Bampton.JPG)

Churchgate House (the old rectory), used as Isobel Crawley's house

Outdoor scenes are filmed in the village of
[Bampton](/wiki/Bampton,_Oxfordshire "Bampton, Oxfordshire") in
[Oxfordshire](/wiki/Oxfordshire "Oxfordshire"). Notable locations include St
Mary's the Virgin Church and the library, which served as the entrance to the
cottage hospital.[14] The old rectory in Bampton is used for exterior shots of
Isobel Crawley's house, with interior scenes filmed at Hall Place near
[Beaconsfield](/wiki/Beaconsfield "Beaconsfield") in
[Buckinghamshire](/wiki/Buckinghamshire "Buckinghamshire").[15]

The Downton Abbey of the title and setting is described as lying in
[Yorkshire](/wiki/Yorkshire "Yorkshire"). The towns of
[Easingwold](/wiki/Easingwold "Easingwold"), [Kirkby
Malzeard](/wiki/Kirkby_Malzeard "Kirkby Malzeard"),
[Kirkbymoorside](/wiki/Kirkbymoorside "Kirkbymoorside"),
[Malton](/wiki/Malton,_North_Yorkshire "Malton, North Yorkshire"),
[Middlesbrough](/wiki/Middlesbrough "Middlesbrough"), [Ripon](/wiki/Ripon
"Ripon"), [Richmond](/wiki/Richmond,_North_Yorkshire "Richmond, North
Yorkshire"), and [Thirsk](/wiki/Thirsk "Thirsk"), each mentioned by characters
in the series, lie in [North Yorkshire](/wiki/North_Yorkshire "North
Yorkshire"), as does the city of York, while [Leeds](/wiki/Leeds
"Leeds")—similarly mentioned—lies in [West Yorkshire](/wiki/West_Yorkshire
"West Yorkshire"). Yorkshire media speculated the general location of the
fictional Downton Abbey to be somewhere in the triangulated area between the
towns of Easingwold, Ripon and Thirsk.[16]

[First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War") [trench
warfare](/wiki/Trench_warfare "Trench warfare") scenes in France were filmed
in a specially constructed replica battlefield for period war scenes near the
village of [Akenham](/wiki/Akenham "Akenham") in rural [Suffolk](/wiki/Suffolk
"Suffolk").[17][18]

Many historical locations and aristocratic mansions have been used to film
various scenes:

The fictional Haxby Park, the estate Sir Richard Carlisle intends to buy in
Series 2, is part of [Waddesdon Manor](/wiki/Waddesdon_Manor "Waddesdon
Manor") in [Buckinghamshire](/wiki/Buckinghamshire "Buckinghamshire").[19]
[Byfleet Manor](/wiki/Byfleet_Manor "Byfleet Manor") in [Surrey](/wiki/Surrey
"Surrey") is the location for the [Dower house](/wiki/Dower_house "Dower
house"), home to Violet, [Dowager](/wiki/Dowager "Dowager") Countess of
Grantham,[20] while [West Wycombe Park](/wiki/West_Wycombe_Park "West Wycombe
Park") in [Buckinghamshire](/wiki/Buckinghamshire "Buckinghamshire") is used
for the interior scenes of Lady Rosamund ([Samantha Bond](/wiki/Samantha_Bond
"Samantha Bond"))'s [London](/wiki/London "London") residence in Belgrave
Square.[21] A house in [Belgrave Square](/wiki/Belgrave_Square "Belgrave
Square") is used for exterior shots.[22]

[Inveraray Castle](/wiki/Inveraray_Castle "Inveraray Castle") in
[Argyll](/wiki/Argyll "Argyll"), Scotland, doubled as "Duneagle Castle" in the
2012 Christmas special.[23]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Byfleet_Manor_House_%28geograph_3492825%29.jpg/220px-
Byfleet_Manor_House_%28geograph_3492825%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Byfleet_Manor_House_\(geograph_3492825\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Byfleet_Manor_House_\(geograph_3492825\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Byfleet Manor](/wiki/Byfleet_Manor "Byfleet Manor") in Surrey is portrayed as
the [dower house](/wiki/Dower_house "Dower house")

[Greys Court](/wiki/Greys_Court "Greys Court") near [Henley-on-
Thames](/wiki/Henley-on-Thames "Henley-on-Thames") in
[Oxfordshire](/wiki/Oxfordshire "Oxfordshire") was used as the family's
secondary property, which they proposed moving into and calling "Downton
Place" due to financial difficulties in Series Three. Also in the third
series, Bates's prison scenes were filmed at [Lincoln
Castle](/wiki/Lincoln_Castle "Lincoln Castle") in
[Lincolnshire](/wiki/Lincolnshire "Lincolnshire").

[Horsted Keynes railway station](/wiki/Horsted_Keynes_railway_station "Horsted
Keynes railway station") in [Sussex](/wiki/Sussex "Sussex") is used as Downton
station.[24] The station is part of the heritage [Bluebell
Railway](/wiki/Bluebell_Railway "Bluebell Railway"). [St
Pancras](/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station "St Pancras railway station")
station in [London](/wiki/London "London") doubled for [King's
Cross](/wiki/London_King%27s_Cross_railway_station "London King's Cross
railway station") station in episode one of series 4, in the scene where Lady
Edith Crawley meets her lover Michael Gregson.[25] The restaurant scene where
Lady Edith meets Michael Gregson and where they share their kiss is filmed at
the [Criterion Restaurant](/wiki/Criterion_Restaurant "Criterion Restaurant")
in [Piccadilly Circus](/wiki/Piccadilly_Circus "Piccadilly Circus") which was
originally opened in 1874.[26]

Bridgewater House in the St James area of London served as the family's London
home. Outdoor scenes are filmed in the village of Bampton in Oxfordshire.
Notable locations include St Mary's the Virgin Church and the library, which
served as the entrance to the cottage hospital. The old rectory in Bampton is
used for exterior shots of Isobel Crawley's house, with interior scenes filmed
at [Hall Barn](/wiki/Hall_Barn "Hall Barn"), Hall Place near Beaconsfield in
Buckinghamshire, featured as Loxley House, the home of Sir Anthony
Strallan.[27]

Parts of series 4 were filmed at [The Historic Dockyard
Chatham](/wiki/Chatham_Dockyard "Chatham Dockyard"), [Kent](/wiki/Kent "Kent")
– The Tarred Yarn Store was used in episode one as a workhouse where Mrs
Hughes ([Phyllis Logan](/wiki/Phyllis_Logan "Phyllis Logan")) visits Mr Grigg
([Nicky Henson](/wiki/Nicky_Henson "Nicky Henson")) and in episode two,
streets at [The Historic Dockyard Chatham](/wiki/Chatham_Dockyard "Chatham
Dockyard") were used for the scenes where Lady Rose MacClare ([Lily
James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James")) is at the market with James Kent ([Ed
Speleers](/wiki/Ed_Speleers "Ed Speleers")) watching her.[28] The production
had previously filmed in [Kent](/wiki/Kent "Kent") for series 1 where the
opening sequence of a train going through the countryside was filmed at the
[Kent & East Sussex Railway](/wiki/Kent_%26_East_Sussex_Railway "Kent & East
Sussex Railway").[29]

Other filming locations for series 4 include the ballroom of The Savile Club
in [Mayfair](/wiki/Mayfair "Mayfair"), London.[30]

Scenes for the 2013 Christmas special were filmed at [Royal Holloway,
University of London](/wiki/Royal_Holloway,_University_of_London "Royal
Holloway, University of London") near [Egham](/wiki/Egham "Egham"), Surrey,
[West Wittering](/wiki/West_Wittering "West Wittering") beach in [West
Sussex](/wiki/West_Sussex "West Sussex") and Berkshire's [Basildon
Park](/wiki/Basildon_Park "Basildon Park") near
[Streatley](/wiki/Streatley,_Berkshire "Streatley, Berkshire"). [Lancaster
House](/wiki/Lancaster_House "Lancaster House") in London stood in for
[Buckingham Palace](/wiki/Buckingham_Palace "Buckingham Palace").[31][32]

[Alnwick Castle](/wiki/Alnwick_Castle "Alnwick Castle"), in
[Northumberland](/wiki/Northumberland "Northumberland"), was the filming
location used for Brancaster Castle in the 2014 and 2015 Christmas specials,
which included filming in Alnwick Castle's [State Rooms](/wiki/State_Rooms
"State Rooms"), as well as on the castle's grounds, and at the nearby semi-
ruined Hulne Abbey on the [Duke of
Northumberland](/wiki/Duke_of_Northumberland "Duke of Northumberland")'s
parklands in [Alnwick](/wiki/Alnwick "Alnwick").[33]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Kingston_Bagpuize_House_%28geograph_2973184%29.jpg/220px-
Kingston_Bagpuize_House_%28geograph_2973184%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kingston_Bagpuize_House_\(geograph_2973184\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kingston_Bagpuize_House_\(geograph_2973184\).jpg "Enlarge")

Kingston Bagpuize House in Oxfordshire as Cavenham Park

In Series 5 and 6, Kingston Bagpuize House in Oxfordshire was used as the
location for Cavenham Park, the home of Lord Merton. In Series 6 (2015) the
scenes of motor racing at [Brooklands](/wiki/Brooklands "Brooklands") were
filmed at the [Goodwood Circuit](/wiki/Goodwood_Circuit "Goodwood Circuit") in
West Sussex. In 2015, Wayfair.co.uk published a map of 70+ Downton Abbey
filming locations.[34]

### Opening[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Opening")]

The opening music of _Downton Abbey_ , titled "Did I Make the Most of Loving
You?",[35] was composed by [John Lunn](/wiki/John_Lunn "John Lunn").[36]

A suite version was released on the soundtrack for the show on 19 September
2011 in the UK and later in the US on 13 December 2011. The soundtrack also
included the song performed by singer [Mary-Jess Leaverland](/wiki/Mary-
Jess_Leaverland "Mary-Jess Leaverland"),[37] with lyrics written by [Don
Black](/wiki/Don_Black_\(lyricist\) "Don Black \(lyricist\)").[38]

## Broadcasts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Broadcasts")]

The rights to broadcast _Downton Abbey_ have been acquired in over 220
countries and territories, and the series is viewed by a global audience of an
estimated 120 million people.[39]

### United
Kingdom[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: United Kingdom")]

The series first aired on the [ITV network](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV
network\)") in the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom")
beginning on 26 September 2010, and received its first Britain-wide broadcast
when shown on [ITV3](/wiki/ITV3 "ITV3") beginning in February 2011.

[STV](/wiki/STV_\(TV_network\) "STV \(TV network\)"), the ITV franchisee in
central and northern [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") (including the
[Orkney](/wiki/Orkney_Islands "Orkney Islands") and
[Shetland](/wiki/Shetland_Islands "Shetland Islands") islands), originally
opted out of showing _Downton Abbey_ , choosing instead to screen a brand-new
six-part series of _[Taggart](/wiki/Taggart "Taggart")_ , following a long
practice of opting out of networked United Kingdom-wide programming on the ITV
network.[40] This led to backlash from Scottish viewers, who were frustrated
at not being able to watch the programme. Many viewers with satellite or cable
television tuned into other regional stations of the ITV network, for example
[ITV London](/wiki/ITV_London "ITV London"), with viewing figures showing this
is also commonplace for other ITV programmes.[41] STV announced in July 2011
that it would show the first and second series of _Downton Abbey_ as part of
its autumn schedule.[42] Scottish cast members [Phyllis
Logan](/wiki/Phyllis_Logan "Phyllis Logan") and [Iain Glen](/wiki/Iain_Glen
"Iain Glen") were both quoted as being pleased with the decision.[43]

### United
States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: United States")]

In the United States, _Downton Abbey_ was first broadcast in January 2011 on
[PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS"), as part of the 40th season of
_[Masterpiece](/wiki/Masterpiece_\(TV_series\) "Masterpiece \(TV
series\)")_.[44] The programme was aired in four 90-minute episodes,
controversially requiring PBS to alter the beginning and endpoints of each
episode and make other small changes, slightly altering each episode's
structure to accommodate fitting the programme precisely into the running-
times allotted.[45][a][b] PBS also added a host ([Laura
Linney](/wiki/Laura_Linney "Laura Linney")), who introduced each episode,
explaining matters such as "the [entail](/wiki/Fee_tail "Fee tail")" and
"Buccaneers"[c] for the benefit of U.S. viewers, which was labelled by some
American critics as condescending.[45] PBS editing for broadcasts in the
United States continued in the subsequent seasons.[46] The fifth began airing
in the United States on 4 January 2015.[47][48][49]

### Canada[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Canada")]

In Canada, [VisionTV](/wiki/VisionTV "VisionTV") began airing the programme on
7 September 2011. Canadian audiences can also view the series on PBS. Downton
Abbey is aired in French on [Ici Radio-Canada Télé](/wiki/Ici_Radio-
Canada_T%C3%A9l%C3%A9 "Ici Radio-Canada Télé").[50]

### Australia and New
Zealand[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Australia and New Zealand")]

In Australia, the first series was broadcast on the [Seven
Network](/wiki/Seven_Network "Seven Network") beginning on 29 May 2011;[51]
the second series was broadcast beginning on 20 May 2012;[52] and the third
series beginning on 10 February 2013.[53] In New Zealand,
[Prime](/wiki/Prime_\(New_Zealand\) "Prime \(New Zealand\)") began airing the
first series on 10 May 2011, the second series on 18 October 2011 and the
third series on 18 October 2012.[54]

### Ireland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Ireland")]

In Ireland, independent television channel [TV3](/wiki/TV3_\(Ireland\) "TV3
\(Ireland\)") aired the first series in January and February 2011.[55]

## Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Reception")]

[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic") ratings per series
![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/4f9db043b794616c5099ae9684f3703c.png)  
---  
|  | [Series 1](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_1\) "Downton Abbey \(series 1\)") | [Series 2](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_2\) "Downton Abbey \(series 2\)") | [Series 3](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_3\) "Downton Abbey \(series 3\)") | [Series 4](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_4\) "Downton Abbey \(series 4\)") | [Series 5](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_5\) "Downton Abbey \(series 5\)") | [Series 6](/wiki/Downton_Abbey_\(series_6\) "Downton Abbey \(series 6\)")  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
Rating | 91[56] | 85[57] | 83[58] | 72[59] | 75[60] | 76[61]  
  
The series has been noted for its relatively sympathetic portrayal of the
[aristocratic](/wiki/Aristocratic "Aristocratic") family, and the class-based
society of early 20th century Britain. This has led to criticism from the
political left and praise from the right.[62] [James
Fenton](/wiki/James_Fenton "James Fenton") wrote in _[The New York Review of
Books](/wiki/The_New_York_Review_of_Books "The New York Review of Books")_ "it
is noticeable that the aristocrats in the series, even the ones who are
supposed to be the most ridiculous, never lapse into the most offensive kind
of upper-class drawl one would expect of them. Great care has been taken to
keep them pleasant and approachable, even when the things they say are
sometimes shown to be class-bound and unfeeling."[63] [Jerry
Bowyer](/wiki/Jerry_Bowyer "Jerry Bowyer") argued in _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes
"Forbes")_ that the sympathy for aristocracy is over-stated, and that the show
is simply more balanced than most period dramas, which he believes have had a
tendency to demonise or ridicule upper class characters. He wrote that
_Downton Abbey_ shows "there is no inherent need for good TV to be left of
center. Stories sympathetic to virtue, preservation of property and admiration
of nobility and of wealth can be told beautifully and to wide audiences."[62]

_Downton Abbey_ has been a commercial success and received general acclaim
from critics, although some criticise it as superficial,
[melodramatic](/wiki/Melodrama "Melodrama") or unrealistic. Others defend
these qualities as the reason for the show's appeal. David Kamp of _[Vanity
Fair](/wiki/Vanity_Fair_\(magazine\) "Vanity Fair \(magazine\)")_ wrote,
"Melodrama is an uncool thing to trade in these days, but then, that's
precisely why _Downton Abbey_ is so pleasurable. In its clear delineation
between the goodies and the baddies, in its regulated dosages of highs and
lows, the show is welcome counter-programming to the slow-burning despair and
moral ambiguity of most quality drama on television right now."[8]

James Parker, writing in _[The Atlantic](/wiki/The_Atlantic "The Atlantic")_ ,
said, "Preposterous as history, preposterous as drama, the show succeeds
magnificently as bad television. The dialogue spins light-operatically along
in the service of multiplying plotlets, not too hard on the ear, although now
and again a line lands like a tray of dropped spoons. The acting is superb—it
has to be."[64] Ben W. Heineman Jr. compared the series unfavourably to
_[Brideshead Revisited](/wiki/Brideshead_Revisited_\(TV_serial\) "Brideshead
Revisited \(TV serial\)")_ , writing "_Downton Abbey_ is entertainment. Its
illustrious predecessor in television mega-success about the English upper
class, _Brideshead Revisited_ , is art."[65] He noted the lack of character
development in Downton. Writing in _[The Sunday Times](/wiki/The_Sunday_Times
"The Sunday Times")_ , [A. A. Gill](/wiki/A._A._Gill "A. A. Gill") said that
the show is "everything I despise and despair of on British television:
[National
Trust](/wiki/National_Trust_for_Places_of_Historic_Interest_or_Natural_Beauty
"National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty")
sentimentality, costumed comfort drama that flogs an embarrassing, demeaning,
and bogus vision of the place I live in."[8]

The first episode of _Downton Abbey_ had a consolidated British audience of
9.2 million viewers, a 32% audience share—making it the most successful new
drama on any channel since _[Whitechapel](/wiki/Whitechapel_\(TV_series\)
"Whitechapel \(TV series\)")_ was launched on ITV in February 2009. The total
audience for the first episode, including repeats and [ITV
Player](/wiki/ITV_Player "ITV Player") viewings, exceeded 11.6 million
viewers. This was beaten by the next episode, with a total audience of 11.8
million viewers—including repeats and ITV Player views.

_Downton Abbey_ broke the record for a single episode viewing on ITV Player,
the ITV online catch-up service.[66]

At [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), which assigns a
[normalised](/wiki/Standard_score "Standard score") rating out of 100 to
reviews from mainstream critics, the first series received an
[average](/wiki/Weighted_mean "Weighted mean") score of 91, based on 16
reviews, which indicates "universal acclaim".[67] This result earned the show
a Guinness World Record in 2011 for "Highest critical review ratings for a TV
show", making _Downton Abbey_ the most critically well received TV show in the
world.[68] Season 4 of _Breaking Bad_ surpassed _Downton Abbey '_s record
later in the year, with a score of 96, making series 1 of _Downton Abbey_ the
2nd highest rated show of 2011.[69]

Sam Wollaston of _[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_ said,

> It's beautifully made—handsome, artfully crafted and acted. Smith, who plays
> the formidable and disdainful Dowager Countess, has a lovely way of
> delivering words, always spaced to perfection. This is going to be a treat
> if you like a lavish period drama of a Sunday evening.[70]

Viewers were critical of the number of advertisement breaks during the first
episode (five in a 90-minute episode, as well as one before and one after),
claiming it ruined the continuity. [ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV
network\)") responded by saying that the number of breaks complied with
[Ofcom](/wiki/Ofcom "Ofcom") regulations and that advertising was necessary to
cover the high costs of production.[71]

The second series premiered in Britain on 18 September 2011 in the same 9 pm
slot as the first series, with the first episode attracting an average
audience of 9 million viewers on ITV1, a 34.6% share.[72] The second episode
attracted a similar following with an average of 9.3 million viewers.[73] In
January 2012, the PBS premiere attracted 4.2 million viewers, over double the
network's average primetime audience of 2 million. The premiere audience was
18% higher than the Series 1 premiere.[74]

The second series of _Downton Abbey_ gave PBS its highest ratings since 2009.
The second series averaged 5.4 million viewers, excluding station replays, DVR
viewings and online streaming. The 5.4 million average improved on PBS first
series numbers by 25%. Additionally, episodes of series two have been viewed
4.8 million times on PBS's digital portal, which bests series one's online
viewing numbers by more than 400 percent. Overall, _Downton Abbey_ -related
content has racked up more than 9 million streams across all platforms, with
1.5 million unique visitors, since series 2's 8 January premiere.[75] In 2013,
_Downton Abbey_ was ranked the 43rd most well-written TV show of all time by
the [Writers' Guild of America](/wiki/Writers%27_Guild_of_America "Writers'
Guild of America").[76]

The third series premiered in the UK on 16 September 2012 with an average of 9
million viewers (or a 36% audience share).[77]

For the first time in the UK, episode three received an average of more than
10 million viewers (or a 38.2% audience share).[78] Premiering in the US in
January 2013, the third series had an average audience of 11.5 million viewers
and the finale on 17 February 2013, drew 12.3 million viewers making it the
night's highest rating show.[79] Overall, during its seven-week run, the
series had an audience of 24 million viewers making it PBS's highest-rated
drama of all time.[79]

While rumoured, due to the departure of actor [Dan Stevens](/wiki/Dan_Stevens
"Dan Stevens"), the death of Matthew Crawley, in the 2012 Christmas special,
drew criticism.[80][81] Lord Fellowes defended the decision stating that they
'didn't really have an option' once Stevens decided to leave.[81] Stevens
later said that he had no say in the manner of his character's departure but
that he was 'sorry' his character had died on Christmas Day.[82]

The fourth series premiered in the UK on 22 September 2013 with an average
audience of 9.5 million viewers—the highest ever for one of the drama's debut
episodes.[83] It premiered in the US on 5 January 2014, to an audience of at
least 10.2 million viewers, outperforming every other drama on that night; it
was the largest audience for [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS") since the 1990 premiere of
the [Ken Burns](/wiki/Ken_Burns "Ken Burns") documentary _[The Civil
War](/wiki/The_Civil_War_\(TV_series\) "The Civil War \(TV series\)")_.[84]

In the UK, the second episode attracted an average of 9.6 million viewers.[85]

The third episode, which aired on 6 October 2013, included a warning at the
beginning: "This episode contains violent scenes that some viewers may find
upsetting."[86] The episode content, in which Anna Bates was raped, led to
more than 200 complaints by viewers to UK television regulator
[Ofcom](/wiki/Ofcom "Ofcom"),[87] while ITV received 60 complaints
directly.[88] On 4 November 2013, Ofcom announced it would not be taking
action over the controversy citing the warning given, that the episode was
screened after 9 pm, and, that the rape took place 'off-screen'.[89]

### Anti-Irish
allegations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Anti-Irish allegations")]

Julian Fellowes supports a united Ireland, "Ultimately, I believe in a united
Ireland. I do come from a long line of Home Rule supporters."[90] Charges,
largely in some Irish media, were made that the series depicts the [Irish
characters](/wiki/Anti-Irish_sentiment "Anti-Irish sentiment") in a negative
light.[91]

[Allen Leech](/wiki/Allen_Leech "Allen Leech"), who plays Tom Branson in the
series, when asked about this by an Irish reporter writing for _The Herald_ ,
denied that the series depicted Irish characters in a stage pejorative
fashion.[91] Tom's brother Kieran, however, is depicted as boorish, rude, and
drunken, and is described by the Dowager Countess as a 'drunken gorilla'[91]—a
reminder to Irish audiences of the ape-like figures depicting the Irish that
were commonly featured in British[92] and American[93] publications in the
late 19th and early 20th centuries.[94][95] The Dowager Countess character who
makes these comments, however, was born in the mid 19th century, and
frequently expresses [Tory](/wiki/Tory "Tory") or [pro-
imperial](/wiki/British_imperialism "British imperialism") views that were
prevalent in England in the late 19th and early 20th century.[94]

Branson's character as an Irishman came in for some criticism in Ireland. _The
Irish Times_ in a mocking review describes the character of Tom Branson as "an
Irish republican turned Downtonian toff" and makes a humorous sarcastic case
for a future Downton Abbey series where Branson "waxes lyrical about how
lovely being part of the British ascendancy is. Then he burns an Irish
flag."[96]

### Allegations of anti-
Catholicism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Allegations of anti-Catholicism")]

The character of the Earl of Grantham occasionally expresses anti-Catholic
views and is described, by _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post
"The Washington Post")_ , as "xenophobic" but "at least historically
accurate".[97]

The series writer, [Julian Fellowes](/wiki/Julian_Fellowes "Julian Fellowes"),
himself a Roman Catholic, explains that he chose to address this in terms of
"that casual, almost unconscious anti-Catholicism that was found among the
upper classes, which lasted well into my growing up years."[98] Fellowes also
stated that he "thought it might be interesting" to explore this in the series
and described his own experiences where the British upper classes "were happy
for you to come to their dances or shoot their pheasants, but there were
plenty who did not want you to marry their daughters and risk Catholic
grandchildren."[98]

###
Authenticity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Authenticity")]

Fellowes tries to be as authentic in his depiction of the period as he can.[8]
Despite this, the show features many linguistic
[anachronisms](/wiki/Anachronism "Anachronism").[99] The accents of characters
have also been questioned with the [Received
Pronunciation](/wiki/Received_Pronunciation "Received Pronunciation") of the
actors who play the wealthy characters described as "slightly more
contemporary" than would be expected among early-20th-century aristocrats,
however, this "elicited more natural and unaffected performances from the
cast."[100]

In 2010, Fellowes hired [Alastair Bruce](/wiki/Alastair_Bruce "Alastair
Bruce"), an expert on state and court ritual, as historical adviser.[101]
Bruce explains his role as being "here to guide the production and
particularly the director as they bring Julian's words to life. That also
involves getting the social conduct right, and giving actors a sense of surety
in the way they deliver a performance."[101] Actor [Jim
Carter](/wiki/Jim_Carter_\(actor\) "Jim Carter \(actor\)"), who plays butler
Carson, describes Bruce as the series "etiquette watchdog",[101] and the UK's
_[Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")_ finished
its 2011 profile of Bruce's role stating "Downton's authenticity, it seems, is
in safe hands."[102] However, historian [Simon Schama](/wiki/Simon_Schama
"Simon Schama") criticised the show for historical inaccuracies and "pandering
to [clichés](/wiki/Clich%C3%A9 "Cliché")".[103] Producer Gareth Neame defended
the show, saying, "Downton is a fictional drama. It is not a history
programme, but a drama of social satire about a time when relationships,
behaviour and hierarchy were very different from those we enjoy today."[104]

A "tremendous amount of research" went into recreating the servants' quarters
at [Ealing Studios](/wiki/Ealing_Studios "Ealing Studios") because [Highclere
Castle](/wiki/Highclere_Castle "Highclere Castle"), where many of the upstairs
scenes are filmed,[105] was not adequate for representing the "downstairs"
life at the fictional abbey.[106] Researchers visited nearly 40 English
country houses to help inform what the kitchen should look like, and
production designer Donal Woods said of the kitchen equipment that "Probably
about 60 to 70 per cent of the stuff in there is from that period."[105] _[Mrs
Beeton's Book of Household
Management](/wiki/Mrs_Beeton%27s_Book_of_Household_Management "Mrs Beeton's
Book of Household Management")_ is an important guide to the food served in
the series, but Highclere owner, and author of _Lady Almina and the Real
Downton Abbey: The Lost Legacy of Highclere Castle_ , Lady Carnarvon, states
that dinner parties in the era "would have been even more over the top" than
those shown.[105] [Lady Pamela Hicks](/wiki/Lady_Pamela_Hicks "Lady Pamela
Hicks") agreed, stating that "it is ridiculous to think that a weekend party
would consist of only fourteen house guests, it would have consisted of at
least 40!"[107] However, Carnavon understood the compromises that must be made
for television, and adds, "It’s a fun costume drama. It’s not a social
documentary. Because it’s so popular, I think some people take it as
historical fact."[105]

## Cultural
impact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=29 "Edit
section: Cultural impact")]

_Downton Abbey_ has been credited with spawning a massive worldwide increase
in demand for professionally trained butlers, especially British butlers,
notably in [China](/wiki/China "China"), [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia"), and
parts of the [Middle East](/wiki/Middle_East "Middle East"). Between 2010 and
2012, demand was thought to have doubled, leading to some butlers fetching
salaries as high as £150,000.[111]

In 2014, China's first school for butlers opened to meet a demand again
attributed to the influence of _Downton Abbey_.[112]

Some of the fashion items worn by characters on the show have seen a strong
revival of interest in the UK and elsewhere during the show's run, including
[starched collars](/wiki/Starched_collar "Starched collar"), [midi
skirts](/wiki/Broomstick_skirt "Broomstick skirt"), beaded
[gowns](/wiki/Ball_gown "Ball gown"), and [hunting plaids](/wiki/Tartan
"Tartan").[113]

The [Equality (Titles) Bill](/wiki/Equality_\(Titles\)_Bill "Equality
\(Titles\) Bill") was an unsuccessful piece of legislation introduced in the
[UK Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the
United Kingdom") in 2013 that would have allowed equal succession of female
heirs to [hereditary titles and peerages](/wiki/British_nobility "British
nobility"). It was nicknamed the "_Downton Abbey_ law" because it addressed
the same issue that affects Lady Mary Crawley, who cannot inherit the estate
because it must pass to a male heir.

The decor used on _Downton Abbey_ inspired [US Representative Aaron
Schock](/wiki/Aaron_Schock "Aaron Schock") to redecorate his congressional
offices in a more luxurious style.[114][115][116] He repaid the $40,000 cost
of redecoration following scrutiny of his expenses and questions about his use
of public money for personal benefit,[117] and subsequently resigned in March
2015.[118]

## Other media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Downton_Abbey&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Other media")]

_The World of Downton Abbey_ , a book featuring a behind-the-scenes look at
_Downton Abbey_ and the era in which it is set, was released on 15 September
2011. It was written by [Jessica Fellowes](/wiki/Jessica_Fellowes "Jessica
Fellowes") (the niece of [Julian Fellowes](/wiki/Julian_Fellowes "Julian
Fellowes")) and was published by [HarperCollins](/wiki/HarperCollins
"HarperCollins").[110][119]

A second book also written by Jessica Fellowes and published by HarperCollins,
_The Chronicles of Downton Abbey_ , was released on 13 September 2012. It is a
guide to the show's characters through the early part of the third
series.[120]

In September 2012, _The Daily Telegraph_ reported Julian Fellowes as saying
that he was working on a spin-off prequel of _Downton Abbey_ that revolves
around Lord Grantham and Cora's romance and eventual marriage as the earl and
countess of Downton Abbey. Initially planned as a book, it was then picked up
by ITV.[121]

Due to the show's popularity, there have been a number of references and
spoofs on it, such as _[Family Guy](/wiki/Family_Guy "Family Guy")_ episode
[Chap Stewie](/wiki/Chap_Stewie "Chap Stewie"), which has Stewie Griffin
reborn in a household similar to Downton Abbey, and _[How I Met Your
Mother](/wiki/How_I_Met_Your_Mother "How I Met Your Mother")_ episode [The
Fortress](/wiki/The_Fortress_\(How_I_Met_Your_Mother\) "The Fortress \(How I
Met Your Mother\)"), where the gang watch a television show called 'Woodworthy
Manor', which is remarkably similar to Downton Abbey. In the episode the
character, Lily, celebrates by viewing an episode of 'Woodworthy Manor'.[122]

In 2015, it was announced that a spin-off prequel television series was in
planning. In April 2015, _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ reported
that Fellowes was planning to be at work on a new period drama series for [NBC
television](/wiki/NBC_television "NBC television"), to be set in late 19th-
century [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), titled _The
Gilded Age_.[123]

In a 2015 interview with _[The Mail on Sunday](/wiki/The_Mail_on_Sunday "The
Mail on Sunday")_ , Fellowes suggested that a younger version of [Maggie
Smith](/wiki/Maggie_Smith "Maggie Smith")'s Dowager Countess character from
his _Downton Abbey_ drama might appear in the new series, saying: "Robert
Crawley would be in his early teens, Cora would be a child. A young Violet
[the Dowager Countess] could make an appearance."[123] As the title suggests,
the series is to be set during the time of America's so-called [Gilded
Age](/wiki/Gilded_Age "Gilded Age") – the industrial boom era in the United
States in the late 19th and early 20th centuries – and portray the upper
echelons of New York's [high society](/wiki/High_society_\(group\) "High
society \(group\)") during that period.[123]

Production and writing for _The Gilded Age_ was updated in January 2016
indicating that filming would start at the end of 2016. As reported in
RadioTimes: "NBC's _The Gilded Age_ is set to start shooting later this year,
Fellowes tells RadioTimes.com. Asked whether he'd written the script yet,
Fellowes said, 'No I haven't, no. I'm doing that this year', before adding:
'And then hopefully shooting at the end of the year.'"[124]

On 4 June 2016, Fellowes was asked by _The Los Angeles Times_ , "Where does
_The Gilded Age_ stand?" Fellowes replied, "It stands really with me up to my
neck in research, and I’m clearing the decks, so that when I start _Gilded
Age_ , I’m only doing _Gilded Age._ These people were extraordinary. You can
see why they frightened the old guard, because they saw no boundaries. They
wanted to build a palace, they built a palace. They wanted to buy a yacht,
they bought a yacht. And the old guard in New York weren’t like that at all,
and suddenly this whirlwind of couture descended on their heads. They
redesigned being rich. They created a rich culture that we still have — people
who are rich are rich in a way that was established in America in the 1880s,
’90s, 1900s. It was different from Europe. Something like Newport would never
have happened in any other country, where you have huge palaces, and then
about 20 yards away, another huge palace, and 20 yards beyond that another
huge palace. In England right up to the 1930s, when people made good money,
they would buy an estate of 5,000 acres and they’d have to look after Nanny.
The Americans of the 1880s and ’90s didn’t want too much of that."[125]

Fellowes and other co-workers on _Downton Abbey_ have indicated in April 2016
an openness to consider possibilities for a feature film production of the
television series after the completion of its final season in 2015.[126]
